Public health and eco-health literacy are not only essential to address climate change but are also essential to address other health pressures such as burgeoning rates of non-communicable diseases,
51 ageing populations and untenable healthcare costs. As Lee et al. outline in their framework for health professional education, the big picture must inform curriculum design to be accountable to societal health needs.
64 Doctors have historically made significant contributions to public health debates and policy discussions. As the greatest health threat of the 21 st century ,
5 it could be argued that a strong public health voice has never been more important. To this end, climate change could be a catalyst for greater public health and eco-health literacy.
